canonical_explanation.text: The d-block elements (transition metals) are located in Groups 3-12 of the periodic table and have partially filled d orbitals in their ground state or in any of their common oxidation states. The first transition series (3d: Sc to Zn) is the most studied. General characteristics include variable oxidation states (due to the similar energies of ns and (n−1)d electrons), formation of coloured ions (due to d-d transitions), paramagnetic behaviour (due to unpaired d electrons), catalytic activity, ability to form complexes, and formation of interstitial compounds and alloys. Atomic radii decrease from Sc to Cr, then remain nearly constant from Cr to Cu due to the balance between increasing nuclear charge and increasing electron-electron repulsion. Ionisation enthalpies generally increase across the series but with some irregularities due to exchange energy stabilisation. The +2 oxidation state is common because the ns² electrons are lost first. The highest oxidation state increases from Sc (+3) to Mn (+7) and then decreases because the increasing nuclear charge holds the d electrons more tightly. KMnO₄ (potassium permanganate) is a powerful oxidising agent where Mn is in the +7 state. It is prepared by fusion of MnO₂ with KOH and an oxidising agent, followed by electrolytic oxidation. In acidic medium, MnO₄⁻ is reduced to Mn²⁺ (colourless); in neutral medium to MnO₂ (brown); in strongly alkaline medium to MnO₄²⁻ (green). K₂Cr₂O₇ (potassium dichromate) contains Cr in the +6 state and is prepared from chromite ore. The chromate-dichromate equilibrium depends on pH: CrO₄²⁻ (yellow, in base) ⇌ Cr₂O₇²⁻ (orange, in acid). K₂Cr₂O₇ is used in volumetric analysis as a primary standard. The f-block elements include the lanthanoids (4f, Ce to Lu) and actinoids (5f, Th to Lr). Lanthanoids predominantly show the +3 oxidation state, exhibit lanthanoid contraction (gradual decrease in ionic radii from La³⁺ to Lu³⁺ due to poor shielding by 4f electrons), and are paramagnetic except La³⁺ and Lu³⁺. Actinoids show a wider range of oxidation states than lanthanoids and are radioactive. The 5f orbitals extend further from the nucleus than 4f, leading to greater participation in bonding.
rules: Transition metals have partially filled d orbitals in their ground state or in any common oxidation state. Zn is not a true transition metal (3d¹⁰ in ground state and +2 state).
Variable oxidation states arise because ns and (n−1)d electrons have similar energies and can both be involved in bonding.
Coloured ions result from d-d transitions: an electron absorbs visible light and jumps from a lower d orbital to a higher d orbital in a crystal field.
Paramagnetism in transition metals is due to unpaired d electrons; the magnetic moment is approximated by μ = √(n(n+2)) BM.
KMnO₄ in acidic medium: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (equivalent weight = M/5).
K₂Cr₂O₇ in acidic medium: Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6e⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O (equivalent weight = M/6).
Chromate-dichromate equilibrium: 2CrO₄²⁻ + 2H⁺ ⇌ Cr₂O₇²⁻ + H₂O. Yellow CrO₄²⁻ in base; orange Cr₂O₇²⁻ in acid.
Lanthanoid contraction: gradual decrease in atomic and ionic radii from La to Lu due to poor shielding by 4f electrons.
Lanthanoid contraction explains why second and third transition series elements (4d and 5d) in the same group have nearly identical radii.
Actinoids show more variable oxidation states than lanthanoids because 5f, 6d, and 7s electron energies are closer together.

questions.question_text: Transition metals are defined as elements that have:

options.text: Completely filled d orbitals in all oxidation states
Partially filled d orbitals in their ground state or in any common oxidation state
Completely filled s and p orbitals

questions.explanation_correct: By IUPAC definition, a transition metal is an element that has a partially filled d subshell in its ground state or in any of its commonly occurring oxidation states. This definition excludes Zn, Cd, and Hg (which have d¹⁰ in both their ground state and +2 state).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Completely filled d orbitals would include Zn-group elements, which are not transition metals. Partially filled f orbitals describe f-block elements (lanthanoids/actinoids). Filled s and p orbitals describe noble gases.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a typical property of transition metals?
questions.explanation_correct: Transition metals generally have high melting points (not low) due to strong metallic bonding involving both s and d electrons. The exceptions are Zn, Cd, and Hg which have weaker metallic bonding (d electrons are not available for bonding as d¹⁰ is fully filled).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Variable oxidation states, coloured compounds, and catalytic activity are all characteristic properties of transition metals. Low melting points are NOT typical — most transition metals have high melting points.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of Cr (Z = 24) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Chromium has an anomalous electronic configuration: [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s¹ instead of the expected [Ar] 3d⁴ 4s². This is because a half-filled 3d⁵ configuration provides extra stability due to maximum exchange energy. Similarly, Cu is [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s¹.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Ar] 3d⁴ 4s² is the expected configuration but is not the actual one due to exchange energy stabilisation. [Ar] 3d³ 4s² 4p¹ places an electron in 4p, which is energetically unfavourable. [Ar] 3d⁶ 4s⁰ would have one extra d electron.

questions.question_text: The colour of transition metal ions is due to:

options.text: d-d electronic transitions that absorb certain wavelengths of visible light
Emission of visible light from the nucleus
Reflection of all wavelengths of light

questions.explanation_correct: In a crystal field, d orbitals split into two sets of different energies. When visible light falls on the ion, electrons in the lower energy d orbitals absorb specific wavelengths and jump to higher energy d orbitals (d-d transition). The transmitted/reflected colour (complementary to the absorbed colour) is what we observe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: UV absorption occurs but is not responsible for visible colour. Light is not emitted from the nucleus. Reflecting all wavelengths would make the substance appear white, not coloured.

questions.question_text: Which of the following ions is colourless in aqueous solution?
questions.explanation_correct: Zn²⁺ has a d¹⁰ configuration — all d orbitals are fully occupied. No d-d transitions are possible because there are no empty d orbitals for the electron to jump into. Therefore, Zn²⁺ compounds are colourless.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cu²⁺ (d⁹) is blue, Fe³⁺ (d⁵) is yellow/brown, and Ti³⁺ (d¹) is purple. All these have partially filled d orbitals and can undergo d-d transitions. Only d⁰ and d¹⁰ configurations are colourless.

questions.question_text: The magnetic moment of a transition metal ion with 3 unpaired electrons is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The spin-only magnetic moment is calculated using μ = √(n(n+2)) BM, where n is the number of unpaired electrons. For n = 3: μ = √(3 × 5) = √15 ≈ 3.87 BM.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.73 BM corresponds to 1 unpaired electron (√3). 2.83 BM corresponds to 2 unpaired electrons (√8). 4.90 BM corresponds to 4 unpaired electrons (√24). For 3 unpaired electrons, the value is √15 ≈ 3.87 BM.

questions.question_text: Among the first transition series elements (Sc to Zn), which element shows the maximum number of oxidation states?
questions.explanation_correct: Manganese (Mn, [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s²) shows the maximum number of oxidation states, ranging from +2 to +7. This is because Mn has the maximum number of unpaired electrons (5 in 3d + 2 in 4s = 7 electrons available for bonding), allowing it to exhibit oxidation states from +2 to +7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sc shows mainly +3. Zn shows only +2. Fe shows +2, +3, and +6 mainly. Mn, being in the middle of the series with 3d⁵ 4s², has the most electrons available for successive ionisation, giving the widest range of oxidation states.

questions.question_text: The atomic radii of transition metals in the first transition series decrease from Sc to approximately which element, and then remain nearly constant?
questions.explanation_correct: In the first transition series, atomic radii decrease from Sc to Cr as increasing nuclear charge pulls electrons inward. From Cr to Cu, the radii remain nearly constant because the added d electrons shield the outer 4s electrons from the increasing nuclear charge, roughly balancing the contraction. At Zn, the radius increases slightly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The significant decrease occurs from Sc to Cr. The near-constancy is observed in the middle and later elements (Cr to Cu). The trend is not limited to Ti-V or Fe-Ni.

questions.question_text: Zinc is not considered a transition metal because:

options.text: It does not form coloured compounds
It has a completely filled d¹⁰ configuration in both its ground state and its +2 oxidation state
It has a low melting point

questions.explanation_correct: By definition, a transition metal must have an incomplete d subshell either in the ground state or in a common oxidation state. Zn ([Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s²) has a full d¹⁰ in both its ground state and in Zn²⁺ ([Ar] 3d¹⁰). Therefore, it does not meet the definition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Zn²⁺ compounds are typically colourless and Zn has a relatively low melting point, these are consequences, not definitions. Zn does form complexes (e.g., [Zn(NH₃)₄]²⁺). The reason is strictly the d¹⁰ configuration in all states.

questions.question_text: Transition metals act as good catalysts because:

options.text: They can provide a surface for adsorption and can adopt variable oxidation states, facilitating electron transfer
They are always in the liquid state at reaction temperatures
They have completely filled d orbitals

questions.explanation_correct: Transition metals are effective catalysts due to: (i) their ability to adopt multiple oxidation states, allowing them to participate in electron transfer steps; (ii) their ability to provide a suitable surface for adsorption of reactants (due to vacant d orbitals); and (iii) the ability to form unstable intermediate compounds with reactants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic mass is not a factor in catalytic activity. Most transition metals are solid at reaction temperatures. Completely filled d orbitals (d¹⁰) actually reduce catalytic activity (Zn and Cu are poor catalysts compared to Fe, Ni, Pt).

questions.question_text: The most common oxidation state of first-row transition metals is:
questions.explanation_correct: The +2 oxidation state is the most common because the two 4s electrons are lost first (they are in the outermost shell and are removed most easily). All first-row transition metals from Ti to Cu show the +2 state (except Sc, which is mainly +3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: +1 is rare for first-row transition metals (seen in Cu⁺ and in some organometallics). +5 is shown by V and few others. +7 is mainly seen in Mn (MnO₄⁻). The +2 state is the most universally observed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following transition metal ions would be expected to have the highest magnetic moment?
questions.explanation_correct: Mn²⁺ has a d⁵ high-spin configuration with 5 unpaired electrons, giving the highest magnetic moment: μ = √(5 × 7) = √35 ≈ 5.92 BM. Ti³⁺ has 1, V³⁺ has 2, and Zn²⁺ has 0 unpaired electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ti³⁺ has μ ≈ 1.73 BM (1 unpaired electron). V³⁺ has μ ≈ 2.83 BM (2 unpaired electrons). Zn²⁺ is diamagnetic (μ = 0). Mn²⁺ with 5 unpaired electrons has the highest μ ≈ 5.92 BM.

questions.question_text: Interstitial compounds of transition metals are formed when small atoms like H, C, N, or B occupy the voids in the metal lattice. These compounds typically have:

options.text: Lower melting points and lower hardness than the parent metal
Higher melting points, greater hardness, and retain metallic conductivity

questions.explanation_correct: Interstitial compounds have higher melting points and greater hardness than the parent metals because the small interstitial atoms distort the lattice and create additional bonding interactions. They retain metallic conductivity and lustre. Their compositions are usually non-stoichiometric (e.g., TiC₀.₅).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interstitial compounds do not have lower properties — they are enhanced. They retain metallic character. They are characteristically non-stoichiometric, unlike ionic compounds.

questions.question_text: Which of the following transition metal ions has a d⁰ configuration?
questions.explanation_correct: Sc (Z = 21) has the configuration [Ar] 3d¹ 4s². When it loses 3 electrons to form Sc³⁺, the configuration becomes [Ar] 3d⁰ — all d orbitals are empty. This is why Sc³⁺ compounds are colourless (no d-d transitions possible).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fe²⁺ is d⁶ (6 d electrons). Cu²⁺ is d⁹. Co³⁺ is d⁶. None of these have empty d orbitals. Only Sc³⁺ and Ti⁴⁺ are common d⁰ ions.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): The E° value for Mn³⁺/Mn²⁺ couple is highly positive, meaning Mn³⁺ is a strong oxidising agent.
Reason (R): Mn²⁺ (d⁵) has a stable half-filled d configuration.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and R explains A. Mn²⁺ has a d⁵ half-filled configuration which is exceptionally stable due to maximum exchange energy. This stability makes it very difficult to remove another electron from Mn²⁺, and conversely, Mn³⁺ has a strong tendency to gain an electron and become Mn²⁺. Hence, Mn³⁺ is a strong oxidising agent (high positive E° for Mn³⁺/Mn²⁺).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are correct. The extra stability of the half-filled d⁵ configuration of Mn²⁺ directly explains why Mn³⁺ readily accepts an electron (i.e., acts as an oxidising agent).

questions.question_text: The highest oxidation state shown by osmium and ruthenium is:
questions.explanation_correct: Osmium (Os) and ruthenium (Ru), which are 4d and 5d elements respectively in Group 8, show the highest oxidation state of +8, as seen in OsO₄ and RuO₄. This is the maximum oxidation state exhibited by any transition metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +4 and +6 are common for many transition metals but are not the maximum for Os and Ru. +10 is not achieved by any element. The +8 state in OsO₄ and RuO₄ is the highest known.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of Mn in KMnO₄ is:
questions.explanation_correct: In KMnO₄: K is +1, each O is −2. So +1 + x + 4(−2) = 0, giving x = +7. Manganese is in its highest oxidation state of +7 in permanganate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +4 is found in MnO₂. +6 is found in K₂MnO₄ (manganate). +5 does not correspond to any common Mn compound. KMnO₄ has Mn in the +7 state.

questions.question_text: When acidified KMnO₄ is used as a titrant, the colour change at the end point is:

options.text: Purple to colourless, then a persistent faint pink

questions.explanation_correct: In acidic medium, MnO₄⁻ (purple) is reduced to Mn²⁺ (nearly colourless). During titration, the purple colour disappears as MnO₄⁻ reacts. At the end point, a slight excess of KMnO₄ imparts a persistent faint pink colour, serving as its own indicator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green is the colour of MnO₄²⁻ (manganate, formed in alkaline medium). Blue is not produced. Orange to green describes dichromate chemistry, not permanganate.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of Cr in K₂Cr₂O₇ is:
questions.explanation_correct: In K₂Cr₂O₇: 2(+1) + 2x + 7(−2) = 0, so 2 + 2x − 14 = 0, giving 2x = 12, x = +6. Each chromium atom has an oxidation state of +6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +3 is found in Cr₂O₃ or Cr³⁺. +4 is in CrO₂. +7 is not a common state for Cr. In K₂Cr₂O₇, Cr is in the +6 state.

questions.question_text:
The chromate-dichromate equilibrium in aqueous solution is:
2CrO₄²⁻ + 2H⁺ ⇌ Cr₂O₇²⁻ + H₂O
When alkali is added to an orange K₂Cr₂O₇ solution, the colour changes to:
questions.explanation_correct: Adding alkali (OH⁻) removes H⁺ from the equilibrium, shifting it to the left: Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 2OH⁻ → 2CrO₄²⁻ + H₂O. The orange dichromate ion converts to the yellow chromate ion. Conversely, adding acid converts yellow chromate to orange dichromate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green is the colour of Cr³⁺ (the reduced form). Blue and red are not typical colours for chromate/dichromate species. The equilibrium shift produces yellow CrO₄²⁻ in basic conditions.

questions.question_text:
In acidic medium, the half-cell reaction for permanganate is:
MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O
The n-factor (number of electrons gained per MnO₄⁻) is:
questions.explanation_correct: In acidic medium, Mn goes from +7 in MnO₄⁻ to +2 in Mn²⁺, gaining 5 electrons per MnO₄⁻ ion. Therefore, the n-factor is 5, and the equivalent weight of KMnO₄ = Molar mass / 5 = 158/5 = 31.6 g/equiv.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The change in oxidation state is from +7 to +2 = 5 units, not 2, 3, or 7. In neutral medium n = 3 (Mn goes to +4 as MnO₂), but in acidic medium it is 5.

questions.question_text: K₂Cr₂O₇ is used as a primary standard in volumetric analysis because:

options.text: It is available in very large quantities
It can be obtained in high purity, is stable, non-hygroscopic, and has a high molar mass
It is a weak oxidising agent
It does not react with HCl

questions.explanation_correct: K₂Cr₂O₇ meets all criteria for a primary standard: it can be obtained in very high purity, it is stable in air and solution, it is non-hygroscopic (does not absorb moisture), and it has a high molar mass (294.2 g/mol), allowing accurate weighing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Availability in large quantities alone does not make it a primary standard. K₂Cr₂O₇ is a strong oxidising agent, not weak. It does react with HCl, liberating Cl₂. The key is its purity, stability, and suitability for accurate standard preparation.

questions.question_text: When KMnO₄ reacts with FeSO₄ in acidic medium, the products are:
questions.explanation_correct: The balanced equation is: 2KMnO₄ + 10FeSO₄ + 8H₂SO₄ → 2MnSO₄ + 5Fe₂(SO₄)₃ + K₂SO₄ + 8H₂O. In acidic medium, Mn⁷⁺ is reduced to Mn²⁺ (MnSO₄) and Fe²⁺ is oxidised to Fe³⁺ (ferric sulphate).
questions.explanation_incorrect: MnO₂ forms in neutral medium, not acidic. K₂MnO₄ (manganate) forms in strongly alkaline medium. Chlorides would only form if HCl were used. In H₂SO₄ medium, sulphates are the products.

questions.question_text: In neutral medium, KMnO₄ oxidises MnSO₄ to MnO₂. The Mn in the product MnO₂ has an oxidation state of:
questions.explanation_correct: In MnO₂, x + 2(−2) = 0, so x = +4. In neutral medium, MnO₄⁻ is reduced to MnO₂ (Mn⁷⁺ → Mn⁴⁺), gaining 3 electrons per Mn atom. This is the brown precipitate observed when KMnO₄ acts in neutral medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +2 is the state in MnSO₄ (the reactant, not the product here). +6 is in K₂MnO₄. +7 is in KMnO₄. The product MnO₂ has Mn in the +4 state.

questions.question_text:
K₂Cr₂O₇ in acidic medium oxidises iodide ions. The balanced half-reaction for dichromate reduction is:
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6e⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O
How many moles of I⁻ are oxidised per mole of Cr₂O₇²⁻?
questions.explanation_correct: Cr₂O₇²⁻ gains 6 electrons. Each I⁻ loses 1 electron to become I₂ (2I⁻ → I₂ + 2e⁻). To balance electrons: 6 moles of I⁻ provide 6 electrons. The overall reaction is: Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6I⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 3I₂ + 7H₂O.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 moles would provide only 3 electrons. 7 relates to H₂O molecules, not I⁻. 14 is the number of H⁺ ions. The electron balance requires exactly 6 moles of I⁻.

questions.question_text: The colour of KMnO₄ solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: KMnO₄ solution is deep purple (violet) in colour due to the intense charge transfer absorption of the MnO₄⁻ ion. This colour is so intense that even dilute solutions appear distinctly purple.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Orange is the colour of K₂Cr₂O₇. Green is K₂MnO₄ (manganate). Yellow is K₂CrO₄ (chromate). KMnO₄ is characteristically deep purple/violet.

questions.question_text: KMnO₄ is not stored in rubber-stoppered bottles because:

options.text: Rubber is attacked and oxidised by KMnO₄ solution, which is a strong oxidiser
Rubber absorbs KMnO₄ and changes colour

questions.explanation_correct: KMnO₄ is a powerful oxidising agent that attacks organic materials including rubber. The MnO₄⁻ ion oxidises the organic compounds in rubber, causing deterioration of the stopper. For this reason, KMnO₄ is stored in dark glass bottles with glass stoppers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: KMnO₄ does not react significantly with glass. It is a non-volatile solid and does not evaporate. The issue is not absorption but chemical oxidation of the rubber.

questions.question_text: The preparation of KMnO₄ involves which intermediate compound?
questions.explanation_correct: KMnO₄ is prepared by first fusing MnO₂ with KOH in the presence of air (or an oxidising agent like KNO₃) to form K₂MnO₄ (green potassium manganate): 2MnO₂ + 4KOH + O₂ → 2K₂MnO₄ + 2H₂O. K₂MnO₄ is then oxidised to KMnO₄ by electrolytic oxidation or by disproportionation in acidic/neutral medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: MnCl₂ and MnSO₄ are Mn²⁺ salts and are not intermediates. Mn₂O₇ is an explosive anhydride of HMnO₄ and is not used in preparation. The key intermediate is K₂MnO₄ (manganate).

questions.question_text: When K₂Cr₂O₇ reacts with concentrated HCl, the gas evolved is:
questions.explanation_correct: K₂Cr₂O₇ + 14HCl → 2KCl + 2CrCl₃ + 3Cl₂ + 7H₂O. The dichromate ion in acidic medium oxidises HCl to Cl₂ gas (greenish-yellow). Cr⁶⁺ is reduced to Cr³⁺ (green CrCl₃).
questions.explanation_incorrect: O₂ is not produced in this reaction. H₂ would require reduction, which is not favoured here. CrCl₃ is a solid product, not a gas. The oxidation of Cl⁻ by dichromate produces Cl₂ gas.

questions.question_text: Lanthanoid contraction refers to:

options.text: The increase in ionic radii from La³⁺ to Lu³⁺
The gradual decrease in atomic and ionic radii from lanthanum to lutetium
The decrease in the number of oxidation states from La to Lu
The contraction of the nucleus in lanthanoid atoms

questions.explanation_correct: Lanthanoid contraction is the gradual decrease in atomic and ionic radii of the lanthanoid elements from La (Z = 57) to Lu (Z = 71). It occurs because the 4f electrons are poor at shielding the outer electrons from the increasing nuclear charge, resulting in a progressive contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The radii decrease, not increase. The number of oxidation states does not systematically decrease. The nucleus does not contract; rather, the electron cloud contracts due to increased effective nuclear charge.

questions.question_text: The most common oxidation state of lanthanoids is:
questions.explanation_correct: The +3 oxidation state is the most stable and common for all lanthanoids. This is because removing three electrons (two from 6s and one from 5d or 4f) achieves a relatively stable configuration. Some lanthanoids also show +2 (Eu, Yb) and +4 (Ce, Tb) due to empty, half-filled, or fully filled 4f configurations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +2 is shown by Eu²⁺ (4f⁷) and Yb²⁺ (4f¹⁴) but is not the most common. +4 is shown by Ce⁴⁺ (4f⁰) and Tb⁴⁺ (4f⁷). +5 is not observed for lanthanoids. The +3 state dominates.

questions.question_text: Lanthanoid contraction is caused by:

options.text: Increase in effective nuclear charge due to poor shielding by 4f electrons
Decrease in the number of protons
Formation of complexes with d orbitals

questions.explanation_correct: The 4f orbitals have a diffuse shape and poor spatial penetration toward the nucleus, making them ineffective at shielding the outer 5s, 5p, 5d, and 6s electrons from the nuclear charge. As atomic number increases, the nuclear charge increases but shielding by 4f electrons is inadequate, leading to a progressive decrease in ionic radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of protons increases, not decreases. The f electrons are not lost in the ground state. Complex formation is a result of lanthanoid properties, not a cause of contraction.

questions.question_text: One consequence of lanthanoid contraction is that the second and third transition series elements in the same group have:

options.text: Nearly identical atomic radii and very similar chemical properties

questions.explanation_correct: Due to lanthanoid contraction, the expected increase in atomic radius from 4d to 5d elements (going down a group) is offset. For example, Zr and Hf have almost identical radii (~160 pm), leading to remarkably similar chemical properties and making their separation very difficult.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They have very similar, not different, properties. Their electronic configurations are analogous but not identical. They show similar oxidation states. The near-identity of radii is the key consequence.

questions.question_text: Ce⁴⁺ is a good oxidising agent because:

options.text: Ce⁴⁺ (4f⁰) readily gains an electron to achieve the stable 4f¹ configuration
Ce⁴⁺ has an empty 4f subshell (4f⁰), which is a stable noble gas-like configuration, making it want to return to Ce³⁺ (4f¹) by accepting an electron
Ce⁴⁺ has a completely filled 4f subshell

questions.explanation_correct: Ce⁴⁺ has a 4f⁰ configuration (empty 4f shell, [Xe] core). While the empty 4f⁰ provides some stability, the Ce⁴⁺ ion has a tendency to gain an electron and revert to Ce³⁺ (4f¹), making Ce⁴⁺ a good oxidising agent. The +4 state is achievable because losing the 4f electron gives an empty, stable subshell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ce⁴⁺ does have 4f⁰, not 4f¹ — gaining an electron gives 4f¹ (Ce³⁺). The 4f shell is empty, not filled. Electronegativity is not the driving force for oxidising behaviour in Ce⁴⁺.

questions.question_text: Eu²⁺ is a strong reducing agent because:

options.text: Eu²⁺ has a stable half-filled 4f⁷ configuration and readily loses an electron to form Eu³⁺ (4f⁶)
Eu²⁺ (4f⁷) tends to get oxidised to Eu³⁺ to achieve a stable +3 state, but the half-filled 4f⁷ provides extra stability to Eu²⁺

questions.explanation_correct: Eu²⁺ has a 4f⁷ (half-filled) configuration, which is stable. However, the most common and stable oxidation state for lanthanoids is +3. Eu²⁺ tends to lose one more electron to form Eu³⁺ (4f⁶), i.e., it gets oxidised. This tendency to lose an electron makes Eu²⁺ a reducing agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eu²⁺ does have 7 f electrons (4f⁷). While Eu²⁺ is paramagnetic, that does not explain its reducing power. The reducing nature is due to the tendency to achieve the common +3 state.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a consequence of lanthanoid contraction?

options.text: Zr and Hf have nearly identical radii and are difficult to separate
All lanthanoids are gases at room temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Due to lanthanoid contraction, the 5d elements have nearly the same radii as 4d elements in the same group. For example, Zr (4d, radius ~160 pm) and Hf (5d, radius ~159 pm) are almost identical, leading to very similar chemical properties and extreme difficulty in their separation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Most lanthanoids are not radioactive (only Pm is radioactive). All lanthanoids are solid metals at room temperature. Lanthanoids do form complexes. The key consequence is the similarity in properties of 4d and 5d elements.

questions.question_text: Actinoids differ from lanthanoids in that:

options.text: Actinoids show a wider range of oxidation states and are all radioactive

questions.explanation_correct: Actinoids show a wider range of oxidation states (e.g., U shows +3 to +6, Pu shows +3 to +7) compared to lanthanoids (mostly +3). This is because 5f, 6d, and 7s orbitals have comparable energies in actinoids. Additionally, all actinoids are radioactive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Actinoids show more, not fewer, oxidation states. They are metals, not non-metals. They have 5f electrons. The greater variability of oxidation states and radioactivity distinguish them from lanthanoids.

questions.question_text: The lanthanoid element that is an exception to the trend and commonly exhibits the +4 oxidation state is:
questions.explanation_correct: Cerium (Ce) commonly shows the +4 oxidation state (Ce⁴⁺). This is because Ce⁴⁺ has a 4f⁰ configuration (empty 4f shell), which provides extra stability analogous to a noble gas core. Ce⁴⁺ is widely used as an oxidising agent in volumetric analysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: La is mainly +3 (it has no 4f electrons to begin with). Nd and Er are predominantly +3. Ce is the most prominent lanthanoid showing the +4 state due to the stability of the 4f⁰ configuration.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about actinoids is INCORRECT?

options.text: Actinoids show a wide range of oxidation states due to comparable energies of 5f, 6d, and 7s orbitals
Actinoids form more stable complexes than lanthanoids
Actinoids have completely filled 5f orbitals in their ground state

questions.explanation_correct: Actinoids do NOT have completely filled 5f orbitals in their ground state. They have partially filled 5f orbitals (ranging from 5f⁰ in Th to 5f¹⁴ in Lr, with most having intermediate fillings). The statement D is incorrect. All other statements are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A is correct (all actinoids are radioactive). B is correct (comparable orbital energies give variable oxidation states). C is correct (5f orbitals extend further from the nucleus than 4f, enabling better bonding). D is the incorrect statement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following transition metal ions would be diamagnetic?
questions.explanation_correct: Zn²⁺ has a d¹⁰ configuration with all d orbitals fully filled, so there are no unpaired electrons. Therefore, Zn²⁺ is diamagnetic (μ = 0). All other listed ions have unpaired electrons and are paramagnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fe²⁺ (d⁶) has 4 unpaired electrons in high-spin. Cr³⁺ (d³) has 3 unpaired electrons. Ni²⁺ (d⁸) has 2 unpaired electrons. Only Zn²⁺ (d¹⁰) has zero unpaired electrons.

questions.question_text: The green colour of K₂MnO₄ changes to purple on acidification because:

options.text: MnO₄²⁻ disproportionates to MnO₄⁻ and MnO₂ in acidic medium
K₂MnO₄ is oxidised by the acid
The green colour simply shifts wavelength in acidic pH

questions.explanation_correct: In acidic or neutral medium, the green manganate ion (MnO₄²⁻, Mn⁶⁺) disproportionates: 3MnO₄²⁻ + 4H⁺ → 2MnO₄⁻ + MnO₂ + 2H₂O. The purple permanganate (MnO₄⁻) and brown MnO₂ are formed. This disproportionation occurs because Mn⁶⁺ is unstable in acidic conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mn²⁺ would require full reduction, not just disproportionation. The acid does not directly oxidise K₂MnO₄. The colour change is a chemical reaction (disproportionation), not a simple pH-dependent colour shift.

questions.question_text: Among the first transition series elements, which element has the highest enthalpy of atomisation?
questions.explanation_correct: Vanadium has one of the highest enthalpies of atomisation in the first transition series due to strong metallic bonding involving both 4s and 3d electrons. The enthalpy of atomisation generally peaks around the middle of the series (V to Cr) where maximum number of unpaired d electrons are available for bonding, then decreases. Mn shows a dip due to its half-filled stable 3d⁵ configuration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sc has fewer d electrons for metallic bonding. Mn has a dip in atomisation enthalpy due to the half-filled d⁵ stability. Zn (d¹⁰) has the lowest atomisation enthalpy because its fully filled d electrons do not contribute to metallic bonding.

questions.question_text: KMnO₄ solution decolourises oxalic acid (H₂C₂O₄) in acidic medium. The reaction initially requires heating because:

options.text: The Mn²⁺ ions produced act as an autocatalyst, but initially there are none present to catalyse the reaction
Oxalic acid decomposes only at high temperature
KMnO₄ is insoluble at room temperature

questions.explanation_correct: The reaction between KMnO₄ and oxalic acid is autocatalytic. Initially, the reaction is slow because there is no Mn²⁺ catalyst. The solution is warmed to ~60°C to start the reaction. Once some Mn²⁺ is produced, it catalyses the remaining reaction, which then proceeds rapidly without further heating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reaction is exothermic, not endothermic. Oxalic acid does not decompose; it is oxidised. KMnO₄ is soluble at room temperature. The initial slowness is due to the absence of the autocatalyst Mn²⁺.

questions.question_text: Promethium (Pm, Z = 61) is unique among the lanthanoids because:

options.text: It is the only lanthanoid that is radioactive and does not have any stable isotope
It has the largest ionic radius among lanthanoids
It does not show the +3 oxidation state

questions.explanation_correct: Promethium (Pm) is the only lanthanoid that has no stable isotopes — all its isotopes are radioactive. It was first produced artificially by nuclear fission. The most stable isotope, ¹⁴⁵Pm, has a half-life of ~17.7 years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +5 oxidation state is not exhibited by Pm. Its ionic radius follows the normal lanthanoid contraction trend. It does show the +3 state like other lanthanoids. Its uniqueness lies in being entirely radioactive.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct electronic configuration of Cu (Z = 29)?
questions.explanation_correct: Copper has an anomalous configuration: [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s¹ instead of the expected [Ar] 3d⁹ 4s². The fully filled 3d¹⁰ configuration provides extra stability due to symmetrical electron distribution and maximum exchange energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Ar] 3d⁹ 4s² is the expected but not actual configuration. [Ar] 3d⁸ 4s² 4p¹ incorrectly places an electron in 4p. [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² would mean Z = 30 (Zn), not Cu.

questions.question_text: Transition metals form alloys with each other due to:

options.text: Similar atomic sizes that allow them to substitute in each other's crystal lattice
Their ability to form coloured compounds

questions.explanation_correct: Transition metals of the same series have similar atomic radii, allowing atoms of one metal to substitute for atoms of another in the crystal lattice (substitutional solid solutions). This forms alloys such as brass (Cu+Zn), bronze (Cu+Sn), and stainless steel (Fe+Cr+Ni).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ionisation energy does not directly determine alloy formation. Magnetic properties and colour are not relevant to alloy formation. The key requirement is similar atomic sizes for lattice substitution.

questions.question_text: The colour of K₂CrO₄ is:
questions.explanation_correct: Potassium chromate (K₂CrO₄) is yellow in colour due to the CrO₄²⁻ (chromate) ion. In acidic solution, it converts to the orange dichromate ion (Cr₂O₇²⁻).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Orange is K₂Cr₂O₇ (dichromate). Green is Cr³⁺ compounds or K₂MnO₄. Purple is KMnO₄. K₂CrO₄ is distinctly yellow.

questions.question_text: The separation of lanthanoids from each other is difficult because:

options.text: They have very different oxidation states
Their chemical properties are remarkably similar due to the similarity in ionic radii of Ln³⁺ ions
They form different types of compounds

questions.explanation_correct: Lanthanoid ions (Ln³⁺) have very similar ionic radii (the difference between La³⁺ and Lu³⁺ is only ~15 pm) and all predominantly show the +3 oxidation state. This leads to very similar chemical properties, making separation extremely difficult. Ion-exchange chromatography is the preferred modern method.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lanthanoids mostly share the same oxidation state (+3), not different ones. They are solid metals, not gases. Their compounds are of similar types, which is precisely why separation is difficult.

questions.question_text: In the chromyl chloride test, K₂Cr₂O₇ is heated with NaCl and concentrated H₂SO₄ to produce:
questions.explanation_correct: When K₂Cr₂O₇ is heated with NaCl and concentrated H₂SO₄, deep red (or orange-red) vapours of chromyl chloride (CrO₂Cl₂) are produced: K₂Cr₂O₇ + 4NaCl + 6H₂SO₄ → 2CrO₂Cl₂↑ + 2KHSO₄ + 4NaHSO₄ + 3H₂O. This test confirms the presence of Cl⁻ ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CrCl₃ is a green solid, not a gas in this context. Cr₂O₃ is produced by thermal decomposition, not this test. Na₂CrO₄ is not the product. The distinctive red vapours of CrO₂Cl₂ are the key observation.

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of lanthanoids is:
questions.explanation_correct: Lanthanoids (Ce to Lu) have the general electronic configuration [Xe] 4f¹⁻¹⁴ 5d⁰⁻¹ 6s². The filling of the 4f orbitals is the defining feature. Some elements like La, Ce, and Gd have a 5d¹ electron in addition to their 4f electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Xe] 5f¹⁻¹⁴ 6d⁰⁻¹ 7s² describes actinoids, not lanthanoids. [Kr] 4d¹⁻¹⁰ 5s² describes the second transition series (4d elements). [Ar] 3d¹⁻¹⁰ 4s² describes the first transition series (3d elements).

questions.question_text: How does the catalytic behaviour of Fe differ from that of Zn in terms of their d-electron availability?

options.text: Fe has partially filled 3d orbitals that provide vacant sites for reactant adsorption and variable oxidation states for electron transfer, whereas Zn has a filled 3d¹⁰ configuration with no vacant d orbitals and shows only the +2 state
Fe and Zn are equally effective catalysts because both are transition metals
Zn is a better catalyst because its completely filled d orbitals provide more electrons for bonding
Fe is a poorer catalyst because its unfilled d orbitals make it unstable

questions.explanation_correct: Fe ([Ar] 3d⁶ 4s²) has partially filled d orbitals, allowing it to adsorb reactants on its surface via vacant d orbitals and to participate in redox cycles through variable oxidation states (+2, +3). Zn ([Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s²) has fully filled d orbitals, so no vacant d orbitals are available for adsorption, and it shows only the +2 state, making it a poor catalyst.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zn is NOT a true transition metal (d¹⁰ in all states) and is a poor catalyst. Completely filled d orbitals do not aid catalysis — vacant d orbitals are required for reactant adsorption. Fe's unfilled d orbitals are precisely what make it an effective catalyst.

questions.question_text: How does the behaviour of KMnO₄ in acidic medium differ from its behaviour in neutral medium in terms of the reduction product of manganese?

options.text: In both media, Mn is reduced to Mn²⁺
In acidic medium Mn⁷⁺ is reduced to Mn²⁺ (colourless), whereas in neutral medium it is reduced to MnO₂ (Mn⁴⁺, brown precipitate)
In acidic medium Mn⁷⁺ is reduced to MnO₂, whereas in neutral medium it is reduced to MnO₄²⁻
In acidic medium the solution turns green, whereas in neutral medium it turns colourless

questions.explanation_correct: In acidic medium: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (Mn goes from +7 to +2, n-factor = 5, solution becomes nearly colourless). In neutral medium: MnO₄⁻ + 2H₂O + 3e⁻ → MnO₂ + 4OH⁻ (Mn goes from +7 to +4, n-factor = 3, brown precipitate of MnO₂ forms). The reduction product depends on the pH of the medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reduction products are different in the two media. In acidic medium MnO₂ is NOT the product; Mn²⁺ is. Green colour corresponds to MnO₄²⁻ (manganate), which forms in strongly alkaline medium, not acidic.

questions.question_text: How does the range of oxidation states exhibited by actinoids differ from that exhibited by lanthanoids?

options.text: Lanthanoids show a wider range of oxidation states than actinoids
Both show only the +3 oxidation state with no variation
Actinoids show a wider range of oxidation states (e.g., +3 to +7 in some cases) because the 5f, 6d, and 7s orbital energies are comparable, whereas lanthanoids are predominantly +3
Actinoids show only the +2 state, while lanthanoids show +3 to +6

questions.explanation_correct: Lanthanoids predominantly exhibit the +3 oxidation state, with occasional +2 (Eu, Yb) and +4 (Ce, Tb). Actinoids show a much wider range — for example, U shows +3 to +6, Np shows +3 to +7, and Pu shows +3 to +7. This is because the 5f, 6d, and 7s orbitals in actinoids have comparable energies, so electrons from all these subshells can participate in bonding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lanthanoids have a narrower range, not wider. Both do not show only +3; actinoids have considerable variation. Actinoids do not show only +2.

questions.question_text: How does the trend in ionisation enthalpy of the first transition series (Sc to Zn) differ from that of main group elements (Na to Ar) across the period?

options.text: Both series show a smooth, monotonic increase across the period

Main group elements show a generally increasing trend with some irregularities, while transition metals show a much more gradual and irregular increase because the added d electrons partially shield the outer s electrons from the increasing nuclear charge
Transition metals show a very steep increase, while main group elements show a gradual increase
Ionisation enthalpy decreases across both series

questions.explanation_correct: In main group elements, ionisation enthalpy generally increases across a period because electrons are added to the same shell with increasing nuclear charge. In the first transition series, the increase is much more gradual and irregular because electrons are being added to the inner 3d orbitals, which partially shield the outer 4s electrons from the growing nuclear charge. Irregularities arise due to exchange energy stabilisation (e.g., at Cr with 3d⁵ and Cu with 3d¹⁰).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neither series shows a perfectly smooth increase — both have irregularities. Transition metals show a gentle, not steep, increase. Ionisation enthalpy does not decrease across either series.

questions.question_text: How does K₂Cr₂O₇ differ from KMnO₄ in terms of their suitability as a primary standard in volumetric analysis?

options.text: Both are equally suitable as primary standards
KMnO₄ is a better primary standard because it is more stable in solution

K₂Cr₂O₇ is suitable as a primary standard because it is non-hygroscopic, highly stable, and obtainable in high purity, whereas KMnO₄ is not a primary standard because its solutions decompose on standing and cannot be accurately weighed to a fixed composition
Neither can be used as a primary standard

questions.explanation_correct: K₂Cr₂O₇ satisfies all criteria for a primary standard: high purity, non-hygroscopic, stable in air and solution, and high molar mass for accurate weighing. KMnO₄, on the other hand, is not a primary standard because its solutions slowly decompose (reacting with traces of organic matter and MnO₂), its purity is harder to guarantee, and it must be standardised against a primary standard like sodium oxalate before use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not equally suitable — K₂Cr₂O₇ is a primary standard while KMnO₄ is not. KMnO₄ solutions decompose on standing and are therefore unstable. Both are oxidising agents used in volumetry, but only K₂Cr₂O₇ qualifies as a primary standard.

questions.question_text: A metal ion in aqueous solution is colourless, diamagnetic (μ = 0 BM), and shows only one oxidation state in all its compounds. Which category does this ion most likely belong to?

options.text: A typical transition metal ion with partially filled d orbitals
A d¹⁰ ion such as Zn²⁺ or Cu⁺
A lanthanoid ion in the +3 state

questions.explanation_correct: Colourless appearance indicates no d-d transitions are possible, which occurs in d⁰ or d¹⁰ configurations. Diamagnetic (μ = 0 BM) means no unpaired electrons, pointing to d¹⁰. Showing only one oxidation state is characteristic of Zn²⁺ (always d¹⁰ in +2) or Cu⁺ (d¹⁰). These d¹⁰ ions are not true transition metals by IUPAC definition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typical transition metal ions with partially filled d orbitals would be coloured and paramagnetic. Lanthanoid Ln³⁺ ions are generally coloured (except La³⁺ and Lu³⁺) and paramagnetic. Actinoid ions with 5f electrons would also show colour and paramagnetism.

questions.question_text: An f-block element commonly exhibits the +3 oxidation state, is part of the 4f series, and its ionic radius decreases gradually across the series due to poor shielding. This element belongs to which category?
questions.explanation_correct: The described properties — belonging to the 4f series, predominantly +3 oxidation state, and gradual decrease in ionic radius (lanthanoid contraction) due to poor shielding by 4f electrons — are the defining characteristics of lanthanoids (Ce to Lu). Actinoids belong to the 5f series and show a wider range of oxidation states.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Actinoids are 5f elements, not 4f. The first transition series involves 3d orbitals, not 4f. The second transition series involves 4d orbitals. The 4f series with +3 dominance and lanthanoid contraction uniquely identifies lanthanoids.

questions.question_text: A first-row transition metal ion has a spin-only magnetic moment of approximately 5.92 BM and forms pale pink compounds in aqueous solution. It can be classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A magnetic moment of ~5.92 BM corresponds to 5 unpaired electrons: μ = √(5 × 7) = √35 ≈ 5.92 BM. Among the first-row transition metal ions, Mn²⁺ (d⁵, high spin) has 5 unpaired electrons with each d orbital singly occupied. Mn²⁺ compounds in aqueous solution are characteristically pale pink.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fe²⁺ (d⁶) has 4 unpaired electrons (μ ≈ 4.90 BM) and gives green solutions. Cr³⁺ (d³) has 3 unpaired electrons (μ ≈ 3.87 BM) and gives green/violet solutions. Cu²⁺ (d⁹) has 1 unpaired electron (μ ≈ 1.73 BM) and gives blue solutions.

questions.question_text: A compound containing a transition metal oxyanion is orange in colour, turns yellow when NaOH is added, and serves as a primary standard in volumetric analysis. This compound can be classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: K₂Cr₂O₇ is orange in colour due to the Cr₂O₇²⁻ ion. When NaOH is added, the dichromate-chromate equilibrium shifts to the left: Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 2OH⁻ → 2CrO₄²⁻ + H₂O, converting the orange solution to yellow (CrO₄²⁻). K₂Cr₂O₇ is a well-known primary standard — non-hygroscopic, highly pure, and stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: KMnO₄ is purple, not orange, and is not a primary standard. K₂CrO₄ is yellow, not orange. K₂MnO₄ is green. The combination of orange colour, yellow on base addition, and primary standard suitability uniquely identifies K₂Cr₂O₇.

questions.question_text: Riya is performing a titration in the school chemistry lab. She takes 25 mL of an acidified FeSO₄ solution in a conical flask and titrates it against KMnO₄ from a burette. She notices that the first few drops of KMnO₄ take a long time to decolourise, but later drops decolourise almost instantly. Which phenomenon best explains this observation?

options.text: The FeSO₄ solution heats up during the reaction, increasing the rate
The Mn²⁺ ions produced in the reaction act as an autocatalyst, accelerating subsequent reduction of MnO₄⁻
KMnO₄ solution becomes more concentrated as the titration progresses
The acid in the solution gets consumed, making the reaction faster

questions.explanation_correct: The reaction between KMnO₄ and Fe²⁺ in acidic medium is autocatalytic. Initially, no Mn²⁺ is present to catalyse the reaction, so the purple colour fades slowly. As the reaction proceeds, Mn²⁺ ions accumulate and catalyse the reduction of further MnO₄⁻ ions, causing subsequent drops to decolourise almost instantaneously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While temperature may rise slightly, the dominant effect is autocatalysis by Mn²⁺. The KMnO₄ concentration in the burette remains constant. Acid consumption would slow the reaction (acid is required), not speed it up. The autocatalytic role of Mn²⁺ is the textbook explanation.

questions.question_text: Amit is studying the magnetic properties of transition metal compounds in his NEET preparation. He measures the magnetic moment of an unknown first-row transition metal chloride MCl₂ and finds it to be approximately 4.90 BM. Using the spin-only formula μ = √(n(n+2)), he deduces the number of unpaired electrons. Which metal ion M²⁺ is most consistent with this data?
questions.explanation_correct: Using μ = √(n(n+2)): for n = 4, μ = √(4 × 6) = √24 ≈ 4.90 BM. Fe²⁺ has configuration [Ar] 3d⁶ and in a high-spin octahedral field (as in FeCl₂), it has 4 unpaired electrons, giving μ ≈ 4.90 BM. Cr²⁺ (d⁴) also has 4 unpaired electrons, but among common MCl₂ compounds, FeCl₂ is the most widely encountered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mn²⁺ (d⁵) has 5 unpaired electrons giving μ ≈ 5.92 BM, not 4.90. Ni²⁺ (d⁸) has 2 unpaired electrons giving μ ≈ 2.83 BM. While Cr²⁺ (d⁴) also gives 4.90 BM, Fe²⁺ in FeCl₂ is the more commonly encountered example at this level.

questions.question_text: Priya is working in a water treatment plant that uses K₂Cr₂O₇ as an analytical reagent. She prepares a standard K₂Cr₂O₇ solution by accurately weighing the salt and dissolving it in distilled water. Her supervisor asks why they use K₂Cr₂O₇ rather than KMnO₄ for preparing the standard solution directly by weighing. Which reason should Priya give?

options.text: KMnO₄ is more expensive than K₂Cr₂O₇
K₂Cr₂O₇ can be obtained in high purity, is non-hygroscopic and stable, making it a primary standard, whereas KMnO₄ solution decomposes on standing and must be standardised against a primary standard
KMnO₄ is a weaker oxidising agent than K₂Cr₂O₇
K₂Cr₂O₇ dissolves faster in water than KMnO₄

questions.explanation_correct: K₂Cr₂O₇ is a primary standard because it is available in high purity, is non-hygroscopic, is stable both as a solid and in solution, and has a high molar mass (294.2 g/mol) for accurate weighing. KMnO₄ solutions decompose slowly due to reaction with traces of organic matter and dust, so its exact concentration cannot be guaranteed by weighing alone — it must be standardised against a primary standard like Na₂C₂O₄.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cost is not the determining factor. KMnO₄ is actually a stronger oxidising agent than K₂Cr₂O₇, not weaker. Dissolution rate is not the reason. The critical distinction is the primary standard criteria.

questions.question_text: Rohan is studying lanthanoid chemistry for his JEE Advanced preparation. He notices that a textbook table shows the ionic radii of Ln³⁺ ions decreasing steadily from La³⁺ (103.2 pm) to Lu³⁺ (86.1 pm). He wonders why the second and third transition series pairs like Zr-Hf have nearly identical radii. Which explanation connects these two observations?

options.text: Zr and Hf have the same electronic configuration, so they must have the same radius

The 14 lanthanoid elements between La and Hf cause a cumulative contraction (lanthanoid contraction) that offsets the expected increase in radius going from the 4d to the 5d series, making Zr and Hf nearly identical in size
Hf is smaller than Zr because it has fewer electrons
The radii are identical because Zr and Hf are isotopes of each other

questions.explanation_correct: Normally, going from a 4d element to the corresponding 5d element in the same group, we expect the atomic radius to increase (additional shell). However, the 14 lanthanoid elements (La to Lu) between the 4d and 5d series undergo lanthanoid contraction — a cumulative decrease in radius due to poor shielding by 4f electrons. This contraction almost exactly compensates for the expected size increase, resulting in Zr (160 pm) and Hf (159 pm) having nearly identical radii.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zr and Hf have analogous but not identical electronic configurations (different principal quantum numbers). Hf actually has more electrons than Zr, not fewer. Zr and Hf are different elements with different atomic numbers, not isotopes.

questions.question_text: Meera is conducting an experiment in which she adds aqueous NaOH to solutions of different transition metal salts. She observes that CuSO₄ solution gives a blue precipitate, FeCl₃ gives a reddish-brown precipitate, and ZnSO₄ gives a white precipitate that dissolves in excess NaOH. She notes that the Cu(OH)₂ and Fe(OH)₃ precipitates are coloured while Zn(OH)₂ is white. What is the best explanation for the white colour of Zn(OH)₂?

options.text: Zn²⁺ has a partially filled d orbital that absorbs only UV light
Zn²⁺ has a d¹⁰ configuration with no vacant d orbitals, so d-d transitions are not possible, and no visible light is absorbed
Zn(OH)₂ is covalent and therefore does not absorb light
Zn²⁺ has no electrons at all, so it cannot absorb light

questions.explanation_correct: Zn²⁺ has the electronic configuration [Ar] 3d¹⁰ — all five d orbitals are completely filled. For d-d transitions to occur, an electron must jump from a lower-energy d orbital to a higher-energy one, but this requires a vacant d orbital. Since Zn²⁺ has no vacant d orbitals, no d-d transitions occur, no visible light is absorbed, and the compound appears white/colourless.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zn²⁺ does not have partially filled d orbitals — it is d¹⁰. Covalent character does not determine whether light is absorbed (many covalent transition metal compounds are coloured). Zn²⁺ has 28 electrons; it is not electron-free.

questions.question_text: Zinc is placed in the d-block of the periodic table along with other transition metals. However, it is NOT classified as a transition metal. Which aspect makes zinc an exception to the d-block classification?

options.text: Zinc does not form any compounds
Zinc has a completely filled 3d¹⁰ configuration in both its ground state and in its only common oxidation state (+2), so it never has a partially filled d subshell
Zinc does not have any d electrons
Zinc has a lower atomic number than the other d-block elements

questions.explanation_correct: By IUPAC definition, a transition metal must possess an incomplete d subshell in its ground state or in any of its commonly occurring oxidation states. Zn ([Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s²) and Zn²⁺ ([Ar] 3d¹⁰) both have fully filled d orbitals. Since zinc never has a partially filled d subshell, it fails the definition despite being in the d-block.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zinc forms many compounds (ZnO, ZnCl₂, ZnSO₄, etc.). Zinc does have 10 d electrons — that is precisely the issue (d¹⁰ is full). Zinc (Z = 30) is the last element of the first transition series, not the lowest in atomic number.

questions.question_text: Students often assume that all transition metals have high melting points due to strong metallic bonding involving d electrons. Which first-row d-block element is a notable exception to this generalisation, and why?

options.text: Fe, because it is too reactive to have strong bonding
Mn, because its half-filled d⁵ configuration makes it a gas at room temperature
Zn, because its completely filled 3d¹⁰ electrons do not participate in metallic bonding, resulting in a relatively low melting point (420°C)
Cr, because its anomalous electronic configuration weakens metallic bonding

questions.explanation_correct: Zinc has a filled 3d¹⁰ configuration, so the d electrons are tightly paired and do not contribute to metallic bonding. Only the two 4s electrons participate, resulting in weaker metallic bonds and a much lower melting point (420°C) compared to other first-row d-block elements like Fe (1538°C), Cr (1907°C), or V (1910°C). Mn also shows a dip but not as extreme as Zn.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fe has a high melting point (1538°C) due to strong metallic bonding. Mn is a solid with a melting point of 1246°C — it is not a gas. Cr has one of the highest melting points in the series (1907°C); its anomalous configuration actually promotes d-electron bonding.

questions.question_text: Among the lanthanoids, the +3 oxidation state is overwhelmingly dominant. However, cerium (Ce) is a well-known exception because it also commonly exhibits the +4 state. What makes Ce⁴⁺ exceptionally stable compared to other Ln⁴⁺ ions?

options.text: Ce⁴⁺ has a half-filled 4f⁷ configuration that provides extra exchange energy stabilisation
Ce⁴⁺ attains a 4f⁰ configuration (empty 4f subshell), which achieves the noble gas [Xe] core and provides extra stability
Ce⁴⁺ has a fully filled 4f¹⁴ configuration
Ce⁴⁺ has the largest ionic radius among Ln⁴⁺ ions, making it the most electropositive

questions.explanation_correct: Ce ([Xe] 4f¹ 5d¹ 6s²) loses 4 electrons to form Ce⁴⁺ ([Xe] 4f⁰), which has an empty 4f subshell and effectively a noble gas [Xe] core configuration. This provides extra stability, similar to how d⁰ or d¹⁰ configurations are stable for d-block elements. Other Ln⁴⁺ ions (except Tb⁴⁺ which gets 4f⁷) do not achieve such specially stable configurations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ce⁴⁺ has 4f⁰, not 4f⁷ (half-filled is Eu²⁺ and Tb⁴⁺). Ce⁴⁺ does not have 4f¹⁴ (fully filled is Yb²⁺ and Lu³⁺). While ionic radius plays a role in some properties, the exceptional stability of Ce⁴⁺ is fundamentally due to the 4f⁰ configuration.

questions.question_text: Why is the +2 oxidation state classified as the most common state for first-row transition metals, and not +1 or +3?

options.text: Because the two 4s electrons are in the outermost shell and are removed most easily, and the energy required to remove additional d electrons is significantly higher
Because d electrons cannot be removed under any circumstances
Because removing one electron would leave an odd electron, which is always unstable
Because the +2 state has the brightest colour among all oxidation states

questions.explanation_correct: The two 4s electrons occupy the outermost shell and have the lowest ionisation energy, so they are removed first. After their removal, the remaining d electrons are in inner orbitals with higher effective nuclear charge, requiring considerably more energy to remove. While many transition metals also show +3 and higher states, the +2 state is the most universally observed across the series (Ti²⁺ through Cu²⁺).
questions.explanation_incorrect: D electrons can be removed — many transition metals show higher oxidation states (+3, +4, etc.) involving d electron removal. Having an odd electron does not inherently make an ion unstable. The colour of an oxidation state has nothing to do with its thermodynamic stability or prevalence.

questions.question_text: Why is lanthanoid contraction classified as a consequence of poor shielding by 4f electrons, and not due to poor shielding by 3d electrons?

options.text: Because 3d electrons are closer to the nucleus than 4f electrons and therefore shield more effectively

Because 4f orbitals have a very diffuse, multilobed shape with poor radial penetration toward the nucleus, making them significantly less effective at shielding outer electrons from nuclear charge compared to d orbitals
Because 3d orbitals have more nodes than 4f orbitals
Because 4f electrons are in the outermost shell and do not need to shield anything

questions.explanation_correct: The 4f orbitals have a complex, diffuse shape with poor radial penetration — they do not extend as effectively toward the nucleus as s, p, or even d orbitals. As a result, 4f electrons are very poor at shielding the outer 5s, 5p, 5d, and 6s electrons from the increasing nuclear charge. In contrast, 3d orbitals have better penetration and provide more effective (though still imperfect) shielding. The cumulative poor shielding by all 14 4f electrons causes the characteristic lanthanoid contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 3d electrons do cause some contraction in the first transition series, but the effect is less dramatic. 4f orbitals actually have more angular nodes than 3d orbitals (l = 3 vs l = 2). 4f electrons are in an inner shell (not the outermost), which is precisely why their shielding ability matters for the outer electrons.

questions.question_text: Why are the anomalous electronic configurations of Cr ([Ar] 3d⁵ 4s¹) and Cu ([Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s¹) classified as a consequence of exchange energy stabilisation, and not simply due to random electron filling?

options.text: Because half-filled (d⁵) and fully filled (d¹⁰) configurations have the maximum number of electrons with parallel spins, which maximises exchange energy — a quantum mechanical stabilisation that lowers the total energy of the atom more than the alternative configuration
Because Cr and Cu are the only elements that have d orbitals
Because the 4s orbital does not exist in Cr and Cu, forcing electrons into 3d
Because exchange energy only operates in atoms with even atomic numbers

questions.explanation_correct: Exchange energy is a quantum mechanical stabilisation that arises when electrons with the same spin occupy different orbitals of the same subshell. It is maximised when all orbitals are either singly occupied (half-filled, as in 3d⁵) or doubly occupied (fully filled, as in 3d¹⁰). In Cr, 3d⁵ 4s¹ has 10 exchange pairs among the five parallel-spin d electrons, more than 3d⁴ 4s² would have. This extra exchange energy more than compensates for the energy cost of moving an electron from 4s to 3d.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cr and Cu are not the only elements with d orbitals — all transition metals have them. The 4s orbital does exist in Cr and Cu; it simply holds only one electron. Exchange energy operates in all atoms regardless of even or odd atomic number — it depends on parallel-spin electrons in degenerate orbitals.
